**Deeplearning**ispartofabroaderfamilyof[machinelearning](/wiki/Machine_learning"Machinelearning")methods,whichisbasedon[artificialneuralnetworks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network"Artificialneuralnetwork")with[representationlearning](/wiki/Representation_learning"Representationlearning")The adjective "deep" in deep learning refers to the use of multiple layers in the networkMethodsusedcanbeeither[supervised](/wiki/Supervised_learning"Supervisedlearning"),[semi-supervised](/wiki/Semi-supervised_learning"Semi-supervisedlearning")or[unsupervised](/wiki/Unsupervised_learning"Unsupervisedlearning").[\[2\]](#cite_note-NatureBengio-2)

Deep-learningarchitecturessuchas[deepneuralnetworks](#Deep_neural_networks),[deepbeliefnetworks](/wiki/Deep_belief_network"Deepbelief

network"),[deepreinforcementlearning](/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"Deepreinforcementlearning"),[recurrentneuralnetworks](/wiki/Recurrent_neural_networks"Recurrentneuralnetworks"),[convolutionalneuralnetworks](/wiki/Convolutional_neural_networks"Convolutionalneuralnetworks")and[transformers](/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model)"Transformer(machinelearningmodel)")havebeenappliedtofieldsincluding[computervision](/wiki/Computer_vision"Computervision"),[speechrecognition](/wiki/Speech_recognition"Speechrecognition"),[naturallanguageprocessing](/wiki/Natural_language_processing"Naturallanguageprocessing"),[machinetranslation](/wiki/Machine_translation"Machinetranslation"),[bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics"Bioinformatics"),[drugdesign](/wiki/Drug_design"Drugdesign"),[medicalimageanalysis](/wiki/Medical_image_analysis"Medicalimageanalysis"),[climatescience](/wiki/Climatology"Climatology"),materialinspectionand[boardgame](/wiki/Board_game"Boardgame")programs,wheretheyhaveproducedresultscomparabletoandinsomecasessurpassinghumanexpertperformance.[\[3\]](#cite_note-:9-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-krizhevsky2012-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

[Artificialneuralnetworks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network"Artificialneuralnetwork")(ANNs)wereinspiredbyinformationprocessinganddistributedcommunicationnodesin[biologicalsystems](/wiki/Biological_system"Biologicalsystem")ANNs have various differences from biological brains

Specifically, artificial neural networks tend to be static and symbolic, while the biological brain of most living organisms is dynamic (plastic) and analog.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Definition\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Definition")\]
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Deep learning is a class of [machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") [algorithms](/wiki/Algorithm "Algorithm") that[\[8\]](#cite_note-BOOK2014-8): 199–200  uses multiple layers to progressively extract higher-level features from the raw inputFor example, in [image processing](/wiki/Image_processing "Image processing"), lower layers may identify edges, while higher layers may identify the concepts relevant to a human such as digits or letters or faces

From another angle to view deep learning, deep learning refers to "computer-simulate" or "automate" human learning processes from a source (e.g., an image of dogs) to a learned object (dogs)Therefore, a notion coined as "deeper" learning or "deepest" learning[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) makes senseThe deepest learning refers to the fully automatic learning from a source to a final learned object

A deeper learning thus refers to a mixed learning process: a human learning process from a source to a learned semi-object, followed by a computer learning process from the human learned semi-object to a final learned object

Overview\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=2"Editsection:Overview")\]
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mostmoderndeeplearningmodelsarebasedonmulti-layered[artificialneuralnetworks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network"Artificialneuralnetwork")suchas[convolutionalneuralnetworks](/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"Convolutionalneuralnetwork")and[transformers](/wiki/Transformer_(neural_network)"Transformer(neuralnetwork)"),althoughtheycanalsoinclude[propositionalformulas](/wiki/Propositional_formula"Propositionalformula")orlatentvariablesorganizedlayer-wiseindeep[generativemodels](/wiki/Generative_model"Generativemodel")suchasthenodesin[deepbeliefnetworks](/wiki/Deep_belief_network"Deepbeliefnetwork")anddeep[Boltzmannmachines](/wiki/Boltzmann_machine"Boltzmannmachine").[\[10\]](#cite_note-BENGIODEEP-10)

Indeeplearning,eachlevellearnstotransformitsinputdataintoaslightlymoreabstractandcompositerepresentationIn an image recognition application, the raw input may be a [matrix](/wiki/Matrix_(mathematics) "Matrix (mathematics)") of pixels; the first representational layer may abstract the pixels and encode edges; the second layer may compose and encode arrangements of edges; the third layer may encode a nose and eyes; and the fourth layer may recognize that the image contains a faceImportantly, a deep learning process can learn which features to optimally place in which level _on its own_

This does not eliminate the need for hand-tuning; for example, varying numbers of layers and layer sizes can provide different degrees of abstraction.[\[11\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2012-11)[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

The word "deep" in "deep learning" refers to the number of layers through which the data is transformedMore precisely, deep learning systems have a substantial _credit assignment path_ (CAP) depthThe CAP is the chain of transformations from input to outputCAPs describe potentially causal connections between input and output

For a [feedforward neural network](/wiki/Feedforward_neural_network "Feedforward neural network"), the depth of the CAPs is that of the network and is the number of hidden layers plus one (as the output layer is also parameterized)

For [recurrent neural networks](/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network "Recurrent neural network"), in which a signal may propagate through a layer more than once, the CAP depth is potentially unlimited.[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13) No universally agreed-upon threshold of depth divides shallow learning from deep learning, but most researchers agree that deep learning involves CAP depth higher than 2

CAP of depth 2 has been shown to be a universal approximator in the sense that it can emulate any function.[\[14\]](#cite_note-14) Beyond that, more layers do not add to the function approximator ability of the networkDeep models (CAP > 2) are able to extract better features than shallow models and hence, extra layers help in learning the features effectively

Deep learning architectures can be constructed with a [greedy](/wiki/Greedy_algorithm "Greedy algorithm") layer-by-layer method.[\[15\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2007-15) Deep learning helps to disentangle these abstractions and pick out which features improve performance.[\[11\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2012-11)

For [supervised learning](/wiki/Supervised_learning "Supervised learning") tasks, deep learning methods eliminate [feature engineering](/wiki/Feature_engineering "Feature engineering"), by translating the data into compact intermediate representations akin to [principal components](/wiki/Principal_Component_Analysis "Principal Component Analysis"), and derive layered structures that remove redundancy in representation
Deep learning algorithms can be applied to unsupervised learning tasks

This is an important benefit because unlabeled data are more abundant than the labeled dataExamples of deep structures that can be trained in an unsupervised manner are [deep belief networks](/wiki/Deep_belief_network "Deep belief network").[\[11\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2012-11)[\[16\]](#cite_note-SCHOLARDBNS-16)

Interpretations\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=3"Editsection:Interpretations")\]
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Deepneuralnetworksaregenerallyinterpretedintermsofthe[universalapproximationtheorem](/wiki/Universal_approximation_theorem"Universalapproximationtheorem")[\[17\]](#cite_note-cyb-17)[\[18\]](#cite_note-horn-18)[\[19\]](#cite_note-Haykin,_Simon_1998-19)[\[20\]](#cite_note-Hassoun,_M._1995_p._48-20)[\[21\]](#cite_note-ZhouLu-21)or[probabilisticinference](/wiki/Bayesian_inference"Bayesianinference").[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)[\[8\]](#cite_note-BOOK2014-8)[\[11\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2012-11)[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13)[\[23\]](#cite_note-MURPHY-23)

Theclassicuniversalapproximationtheoremconcernsthecapacityof[feedforwardneuralnetworks](/wiki/Feedforward_neural_networks"Feedforwardneuralnetworks")withasinglehiddenlayeroffinitesizetoapproximate[continuousfunctions](/wiki/Continuous_functions"Continuousfunctions").[\[17\]](#cite_note-cyb-17)[\[18\]](#cite_note-horn-18)[\[19\]](#cite_note-Haykin,_Simon_1998-19)[\[20\]](#cite_note-Hassoun,_M._1995_p._48-20)In1989,thefirstproofwaspublishedby[GeorgeCybenko](/wiki/George_Cybenko"GeorgeCybenko")for

[sigmoid](/wiki/Sigmoid_function"Sigmoidfunction")activationfunctions[\[17\]](#cite_note-cyb-17)andwasgeneralisedtofeed-forwardmulti-layerarchitecturesin1991byKurtHornik.[\[18\]](#cite_note-horn-18)Recentworkalsoshowedthatuniversalapproximationalsoholdsfornon-boundedactivationfunctionssuchas[KunihikoFukushima](/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima"KunihikoFukushima")'s[rectifiedlinearunit](/wiki/Rectified_linear_unit"Rectifiedlinearunit").[\[24\]](#cite_note-Fukushima1969-24)[\[25\]](#cite_note-sonoda17-25)

Theuniversalapproximationtheoremfor[deepneuralnetworks](/wiki/Deep_neural_network"Deepneuralnetwork")concernsthecapacityofnetworkswithboundedwidthbutthedepthisallowedtogrowLu et al.[\[21\]](#cite_note-ZhouLu-21) proved that if the width of a [deep neural network](/wiki/Deep_neural_network "Deep neural network") with [ReLU](/wiki/ReLU "ReLU") activation is strictly larger than the input dimension, then the network can approximate any [Lebesgue integrable function](/wiki/Lebesgue_integration "Lebesgue integration"); if the width is smaller or equal to the input dimension, then a [deep neural network](/wiki/Deep_neural_network "Deep neural network") is not a universal approximator
The [probabilistic](/wiki/Probabilistic "Probabilistic") interpretation[\[23\]](#cite_note-MURPHY-23) derives from the field of [machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning")

It features inference,[\[8\]](#cite_note-BOOK2014-8)[\[10\]](#cite_note-BENGIODEEP-10)[\[11\]](#cite_note-BENGIO2012-11)[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13)[\[16\]](#cite_note-SCHOLARDBNS-16)[\[23\]](#cite_note-MURPHY-23) as well as the [optimization](/wiki/Optimization "Optimization") concepts of [training](/wiki/Training "Training") and [testing](/wiki/Test_(assessment) "Test (assessment)"), related to fitting and [generalization](/wiki/Generalization "Generalization"), respectivelyMore specifically, the probabilistic interpretation considers the activation nonlinearity as a [cumulative distribution function](/wiki/Cumulative_distribution_function "Cumulative distribution function").[\[23\]](#cite_note-MURPHY-23) The probabilistic interpretation led to the introduction of [dropout](/wiki/Dropout_(neural_networks) "Dropout (neural networks)") as [regularizer](/wiki/Regularization_(mathematics) "Regularization (mathematics)") in neural networksThe probabilistic interpretation was introduced by researchers including [Hopfield](/wiki/John_Hopfield "John Hopfield"), [Widrow](/wiki/Bernard_Widrow "Bernard Widrow") and [Narendra](/wiki/Kumpati_S._Narendra "Kumpati S

Narendra") and popularized in surveys such as the one by [Bishop](/wiki/Christopher_Bishop "Christopher Bishop").[\[26\]](#cite_note-prml-26)

History\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: History")\]
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There are two types of neural networks: [feedforward neural networks](/wiki/Feedforward_neural_networks "Feedforward neural networks") (FNNs) and [recurrent neural networks](/wiki/Recurrent_neural_networks "Recurrent neural networks") (RNNs)RNNs have cycles in their connectivity structure, FNNs don'tIn the 1920s, [Wilhelm Lenz](/wiki/Wilhelm_Lenz "Wilhelm Lenz") and [Ernst Ising](/wiki/Ernst_Ising "Ernst Ising") created and analyzed the [Ising model](/wiki/Ising_model "Ising model")[\[27\]](#cite_note-brush67-27) which is essentially a non-learning RNN architecture consisting of neuron-like threshold elements

In 1972, [Shun'ichi Amari](/wiki/Shun%27ichi_Amari "Shun'ichi Amari") made this architecture adaptive.[\[28\]](#cite_note-Amari1972-28)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) His learning RNN was popularised by [John Hopfield](/wiki/John_Hopfield "John Hopfield") in 1982.[\[30\]](#cite_note-Hopfield1982-30) RNNs have become central for [speech recognition](/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition") and [language processing](/wiki/Language_processing "Language processing")

Charles Tappert writes that [Frank Rosenblatt](/wiki/Frank_Rosenblatt "Frank Rosenblatt") developed and explored all of the basic ingredients of the deep learning systems of today,[\[31\]](#cite_note-Who_Is_the_Father_of_Deep_Learning?-31) referring to Rosenblatt's 1962 book[\[32\]](#cite_note-rosenblatt1962-32) which introduced a [multilayer perceptron](/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron "Multilayer perceptron") (MLP) with 3 layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with randomized weights that did not learn, and an output layer.[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) However, since only the output layer had learning connections, this was not yet deep learningItwaswhatlaterwascalledan[extremelearningmachine](/wiki/Extreme_learning_machine"Extremelearningmachine").[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29)

Thefirstgeneral,workinglearningalgorithmforsupervised,deep,feedforward,multilayer[perceptrons](/wiki/Perceptron"Perceptron")waspublishedby[AlexeyIvakhnenko](/wiki/Alexey_Ivakhnenko"AlexeyIvakhnenko")andLapain1967.[\[33\]](#cite_note-ivak1965-33)A1971paperdescribedadeepnetworkwitheightlayerstrainedbythe[groupmethodofdatahandling](/wiki/Group_method_of_data_handling"Groupmethodofdatahandling").[\[34\]](#cite_note-ivak1971-34)

Thefirstdeeplearning[multilayerperceptron](/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron"Multilayerperceptron")trainedby[stochasticgradient

descent](/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent"Stochasticgradientdescent")[\[35\]](#cite_note-robbins1951-35)waspublishedin1967by[Shun'ichiAmari](/wiki/Shun%27ichi_Amari"Shun'ichiAmari").[\[36\]](#cite_note-Amari1967-36)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29)IncomputerexperimentsconductedbyAmari'sstudentSaito,afivelayerMLPwithtwomodifiablelayerslearned[internalrepresentations](/wiki/Knowledge_representation"Knowledgerepresentation")toclassifynon-linearilyseparablepatternclasses.[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29)In1987MatthewBrandreportedthatwide12-layernonlinearperceptronscouldbefullyend-to-endtrainedtoreproducelogicfunctionsofnontrivialcircuitdepthviagradientdescentonsmallbatchesofrandominput/outputsamples,butconcludedthattrainingtimeoncontemporaryhardware(sub-megaflopcomputers)madethetechniqueimpractical,andproposedusingfixedrandomearlylayersasaninputhashforasinglemodifiablelayer.[\[37\]](#cite_note-Brand1988-37)Instead,subsequentdevelopmentsinhardwareandhyperparametertuningshavemadeend-to-end[stochasticgradientdescent](/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent"Stochasticgradientdescent")thecurrentlydominanttrainingtechnique

In 1970, [Seppo Linnainmaa](/wiki/Seppo_Linnainmaa "Seppo Linnainmaa") published the reverse mode of [automatic differentiation](/wiki/Automatic_differentiation "Automatic differentiation") of discrete connected networks of nested [differentiable](/wiki/Differentiable_function "Differentiable function") functions.[\[38\]](#cite_note-lin1970-38)[\[39\]](#cite_note-lin1976-39)[\[40\]](#cite_note-grie2012-40) This became known as [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation").[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13) It is an efficient application of the [chain rule](/wiki/Chain_rule "Chain rule") derived by [Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz](/wiki/Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz "Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz") in 1673[\[41\]](#cite_note-leibniz1676-41) to networks of differentiable nodes.[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) The terminology "back-propagating errors" was actually introduced in 1962 by Rosenblatt,[\[32\]](#cite_note-rosenblatt1962-32)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) but he did not know how to implement this, although [Henry J

Kelley](/wiki/Henry_J._Kelley "Henry JKelley") had a continuous precursor of [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation")[\[42\]](#cite_note-kelley1960-42) already in 1960 in the context of [control theory](/wiki/Control_theory "Control theory").[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) In 1982, [Paul Werbos](/wiki/Paul_Werbos "Paul Werbos") applied [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") to MLPs in the way that has become standard.[\[43\]](#cite_note-werbos1982-43)[\[44\]](#cite_note-WERBOS1974-44)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) In 1985, [David ERumelhart](/wiki/David_E._Rumelhart "David ERumelhart") et al

published an experimental analysis of the technique.[\[45\]](#cite_note-rumelhart1986-45)

Deep learning architectures for [convolutional neural networks](/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network "Convolutional neural network") (CNNs) with convolutional layers and downsampling layers began with the [Neocognitron](/wiki/Neocognitron "Neocognitron") introduced by [Kunihiko Fukushima](/wiki/Kunihiko_Fukushima "Kunihiko Fukushima") in 1980.[\[46\]](#cite_note-FUKU1980-46) In 1969, he also introduced the [ReLU](/wiki/Rectifier_(neural_networks) "Rectifier (neural networks)") (rectified linear unit) [activation function](/wiki/Activation_function "Activation function").[\[24\]](#cite_note-Fukushima1969-24)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) The rectifier has become the most popular activation function for CNNs and deep learning in general.[\[47\]](#cite_note-47) CNNs have become an essential tool for [computer vision](/wiki/Computer_vision "Computer vision")

The term _Deep Learning_ was introduced to the machine learning community by [Rina Dechter](/wiki/Rina_Dechter "Rina Dechter") in 1986,[\[48\]](#cite_note-dechter1986-48) and to [artificial neural networks](/wiki/Artificial_Neural_Networks "Artificial Neural Networks") by Igor Aizenberg and colleagues in 2000, in the context of [Boolean](/wiki/Boolean_network "Boolean network") threshold neurons.[\[49\]](#cite_note-aizenberg2000-49)[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)

In 1988, Wei Zhang et alapplied the [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") algorithm to a [convolutional neural network](/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network "Convolutional neural network") (a simplified Neocognitron with convolutional interconnections between the image feature layers and the last fully connected layer) for alphabet recognition

They also proposed an implementation of the CNN with an optical computing system.[\[51\]](#cite_note-wz1988-51)[\[52\]](#cite_note-wz1990-52) In 1989, [Yann LeCun](/wiki/Yann_LeCun "Yann LeCun") et alapplied [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") to a CNN with the purpose of [recognizing handwritten ZIP codes](/wiki/Handwriting_recognition "Handwriting recognition") on mailWhile the algorithm worked, training required 3 days.[\[53\]](#cite_note-LECUN1989-53) Subsequently, Wei Zhang, et al

modified their model by removing the last fully connected layer and applied it for medical image object segmentation in 1991[\[54\]](#cite_note-54) and breast cancer detection in mammograms in 1994.[\[55\]](#cite_note-55) LeNet-5 (1998), a 7-level CNN by [Yann LeCun](/wiki/Yann_LeCun "Yann LeCun") et al.,[\[56\]](#cite_note-lecun98-56) that classifies digits, was applied by several banks to recognize hand-written numbers on checks digitized in 32x32 pixel images
In the 1980s, [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") did not work well for deep learning with long credit assignment paths

To overcome this problem, [Jürgen Schmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber "Jürgen Schmidhuber") (1992) proposed a hierarchy of RNNs pre-trained one level at a time by [self-supervised learning](/wiki/Self-supervised_learning "Self-supervised learning").[\[57\]](#cite_note-schmidhuber1992-57) It uses [predictive coding](/wiki/Predictive_coding "Predictive coding") to learn [internal representations](/wiki/Knowledge_representation "Knowledge representation") at multiple self-organizing time scalesThis can substantially facilitate downstream deep learning

The RNN hierarchy can be _collapsed_ into a single RNN, by [distilling](/wiki/Knowledge_distillation "Knowledge distillation") a higher level _chunker_ network into a lower level _automatizer_ network.[\[57\]](#cite_note-schmidhuber1992-57)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) In 1993, a chunker solved a deep learning task whose depth exceeded 1000.[\[58\]](#cite_note-schmidhuber1993-58)

In 1992, [Jürgen Schmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber "Jürgen Schmidhuber") also published an _alternative to RNNs_[\[59\]](#cite_note-transform1992-59) which is now called a _linear [Transformer](/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model) "Transformer (machine learning model)")_ or a Transformer with linearized [self-attention](/wiki/Attention_(machine_learning) "Attention (machine learning)")[\[60\]](#cite_note-schlag2021-60)[\[61\]](#cite_note-choromanski2020-61)[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) (save for a normalization operator)

It learns _internal spotlights of attention_:[\[62\]](#cite_note-attention1993-62) a slow [feedforward neural network](/wiki/Feedforward_neural_network "Feedforward neural network") learns by [gradient descent](/wiki/Gradient_descent "Gradient descent") to control the fast weights of another neural network through [outer products](/wiki/Outer_product "Outer product") of self-generated activation patterns _FROM_ and _TO_ (which are now called _key_ and _value_ for [self-attention](/wiki/Attention_(machine_learning) "Attention (machine learning)")).[\[60\]](#cite_note-schlag2021-60) This fast weight _attention mapping_ is applied to a query pattern
The modern [Transformer](/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model) "Transformer (machine learning model)") was introduced by Ashish Vaswani etal

in their 2017 paper "Attention Is All You Need".[\[63\]](#cite_note-vaswani2017-63) It combines this with a [softmax](/wiki/Softmax "Softmax") operator and a projection matrix.[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) Transformers have increasingly become the model of choice for [natural language processing](/wiki/Natural_language_processing "Natural language processing").[\[64\]](#cite_note-wolf2020-64) Many modern large language models such as [ChatGPT](/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT"), [GPT-4](/wiki/GPT-4 "GPT-4"), and [BERT](/wiki/BERT_(language_model) "BERT (language model)") use it

Transformers are also increasingly being used in [computer vision](/wiki/Computer_vision "Computer vision").[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)

In 1991, [Jürgen Schmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber "Jürgen Schmidhuber") also published adversarial [neural networks](/wiki/Neural_network "Neural network") that contest with each other in the form of a [zero-sum game](/wiki/Zero-sum_game "Zero-sum game"), where one network's gain is the other network's loss.[\[66\]](#cite_note-curiosity1991-66)[\[67\]](#cite_note-fun2010-67)[\[68\]](#cite_note-gancurpm2020-68) The first network is a [generative model](/wiki/Generative_model "Generative model") that models a [probability distribution](/wiki/Probability_distribution "Probability distribution") over output patterns

The second network learns by [gradient descent](/wiki/Gradient_descent "Gradient descent") to predict the reactions of the environment to these patternsThis was called "artificial curiosity"In 2014, this principle was used in a [generative adversarial network](/wiki/Generative_adversarial_network "Generative adversarial network") (GAN) by [Ian Goodfellow](/wiki/Ian_Goodfellow "Ian Goodfellow") et al.[\[69\]](#cite_note-GANnips-69) Here the environmental reaction is 1 or 0 depending on whether the first network's output is in a given set

This can be used to create realistic [deepfakes](/wiki/Deepfake "Deepfake").[\[70\]](#cite_note-70) Excellent image quality is achieved by [Nvidia](/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia")'s [StyleGAN](/wiki/StyleGAN "StyleGAN") (2018)[\[71\]](#cite_note-SyncedReview2018-71) based on the Progressive GAN by Tero Karras etal.[\[72\]](#cite_note-progressiveGAN2017-72) Here the GAN generator is grown from small to large scale in a pyramidal fashion

[Sepp Hochreiter](/wiki/Sepp_Hochreiter "Sepp Hochreiter")'s diploma thesis (1991)[\[73\]](#cite_note-HOCH1991-73) was called "one of the most important documents in the history of machine learning" by his supervisor [Schmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber "Jürgen Schmidhuber").[\[29\]](#cite_note-DLhistory-29) It not only tested the neural history compressor,[\[57\]](#cite_note-schmidhuber1992-57) but also identified and analyzed the [vanishing gradient problem](/wiki/Vanishing_gradient_problem "Vanishing gradient problem").[\[73\]](#cite_note-HOCH1991-73)[\[74\]](#cite_note-HOCH2001-74) Hochreiter proposed recurrent [residual](/wiki/Residual_neural_network "Residual neural network") connections to solve this problem

Both shallow and deep learning (e.g., recurrent nets) of ANNs for [speech recognition](/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition") have been explored for many years.[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)[\[84\]](#cite_note-Robinson1992-84)[\[85\]](#cite_note-85) These methods never outperformed non-uniform internal-handcrafting Gaussian [mixture model](/wiki/Mixture_model "Mixture model")/[Hidden Markov model](/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model "Hidden Markov model") (GMM-HMM) technology based on generative models of speech trained discriminatively.[\[86\]](#cite_note-Baker2009-86) Key difficulties have been analyzed, including gradient diminishing[\[73\]](#cite_note-HOCH1991-73) and weak temporal correlation structure in neural predictive models.[\[87\]](#cite_note-Bengio1991-87)[\[88\]](#cite_note-Deng1994-88) Additional difficulties were the lack of training data and limited computing power

### Deep learning revolution\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Deep learning revolution")\]

[](/wiki/File:AI-ML-DL.svg)

How deep learning is a subset of machine learning and how machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence (AI)

In the late 2000s, deep learning started to outperform other methods in [machine learning](/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") competitions

In 2009, a [long short-term memory](/wiki/Long_short-term_memory "Long short-term memory") trained by [connectionist temporal classification](/wiki/Connectionist_temporal_classification "Connectionist temporal classification") ([Alex Graves](/wiki/Alex_Graves_(computer_scientist) "Alex Graves (computer scientist)"), Santiago Fernández, Faustino Gomez, and [Jürgen Schmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber "Jürgen Schmidhuber"), 2006)[\[93\]](#cite_note-graves2006-93) was the first RNN to win [pattern recognition](/wiki/Pattern_recognition "Pattern recognition") contests, winning three competitions in connected [handwriting recognition](/wiki/Handwriting_recognition "Handwriting recognition").[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13) [Google](/wiki/Google "Google") later used CTC-trained LSTM for speech recognition on the [smartphone](/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone").[\[122\]](#cite_note-GoogleVoiceTranscription-122)[\[95\]](#cite_note-sak2015-95)

Significant impacts in image or object recognition were felt from 2011 to 2012

Although CNNs trained by [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation") had been around for decades,[\[51\]](#cite_note-wz1988-51)[\[53\]](#cite_note-LECUN1989-53) and GPU implementations of NNs for years,[\[115\]](#cite_note-jung2004-115) including CNNs,[\[117\]](#cite_note-chellapilla2006-117)[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13) faster implementations of CNNs on GPUs were needed to progress on computer visionIn2011,the_DanNet_[\[123\]](#cite_note-:6-123)[\[3\]](#cite_note-:9-3)byDanCiresan,UeliMeier,JonathanMasci,[LucaMariaGambardella](/wiki/Luca_Maria_Gambardella"LucaMariaGambardella"),and[JürgenSchmidhuber](/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Schmidhuber"JürgenSchmidhuber")achievedforthefirsttimesuperhumanperformanceinavisualpatternrecognitioncontest,outperformingtraditionalmethodsbyafactorof3.[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13)Alsoin2011,DanNetwontheICDARChinesehandwritingcontest,andinMay2012,itwontheISBIimagesegmentationcontest.[\[124\]](#cite_note-:8-124)Until2011,CNNsdidnotplayamajorroleatcomputervisionconferences,butinJune2012,apaperbyCiresanetal
at the leading conference CVPR[\[3\]](#cite_note-:9-3) showed how [max-pooling](/wiki/Max_pooling "Max pooling") CNNs on GPU can dramatically improve many vision benchmark records

In September 2012, DanNet also won the ICPR contest on analysis of large medical images for cancer detection, and in the following year also the MICCAI Grand Challenge on the same topic.[\[125\]](#cite_note-ciresan2013miccai-125) In October 2012, the similar [AlexNet](/wiki/AlexNet "AlexNet") by [Alex Krizhevsky](/wiki/Alex_Krizhevsky "Alex Krizhevsky"), [Ilya Sutskever](/wiki/Ilya_Sutskever "Ilya Sutskever"), and [Geoffrey Hinton](/wiki/Geoffrey_Hinton "Geoffrey Hinton")[\[4\]](#cite_note-krizhevsky2012-4) won the large-scale [ImageNet competition](/wiki/ImageNet_competition "ImageNet competition") by a significant margin over shallow machine learning methods

The VGG-16 network by [Karen Simonyan](/wiki/Karen_Simonyan "Karen Simonyan") and [Andrew Zisserman](/wiki/Andrew_Zisserman "Andrew Zisserman")[\[126\]](#cite_note-VGG-126) further reduced the error rate and won the ImageNet 2014 competition, following a similar trend in large-scale speech recognition
Image classification was then extended to the more challenging task of [generating descriptions](/wiki/Automatic_image_annotation "Automatic image annotation") (captions) for images, often as a combination of CNNs and LSTMs.[\[127\]](#cite_note-1411.4555-127)[\[128\]](#cite_note-1411.4952-128)[\[129\]](#cite_note-1411.2539-129)

In 2012, a team led by George EDahlwonthe"MerckMolecularActivityChallenge"usingmulti-taskdeepneuralnetworkstopredictthe[biomoleculartarget](/wiki/Biomolecular_target"Biomoleculartarget")ofonedrug.[\[130\]](#cite_note-MERCK2012-130)[\[131\]](#cite_note-:5-131)In2014,[SeppHochreiter](/wiki/Sepp_Hochreiter"SeppHochreiter")'sgroupuseddeeplearningtodetectoff-targetandtoxiceffectsofenvironmentalchemicalsinnutrients,householdproductsanddrugsandwonthe"Tox21DataChallenge"of[NIH](/wiki/NIH"NIH"),[FDA](/wiki/FDA"FDA")and[NCATS](/wiki/National_Center_for_Advancing_Translational_Sciences"NationalCenterforAdvancingTranslational

Sciences").[\[132\]](#cite_note-TOX21-132)[\[133\]](#cite_note-TOX21Data-133)[\[134\]](#cite_note-:11-134)

In2016,RogerParloffmentioneda"deeplearningrevolution"thathastransformedtheAIindustry.[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)

Neural networks\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Neural networks")\]
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Main article: [Artificial neural network](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network "Artificial neural network")

[](/wiki/File:Simplified_neural_network_training_example.svg)

Simplified example of training a neural network in object detection: The network is trained by multiple images that are known to depict [starfish](/wiki/Starfish "Starfish") and [sea urchins](/wiki/Sea_urchin "Sea urchin"), which are correlated with "nodes" that represent visual [features](/wiki/Feature_(computer_vision) "Feature (computer vision)")The starfish match with a ringed texture and a star outline, whereas most sea urchins match with a striped texture and oval shape

However, the instance of a ring textured sea urchin creates a weakly weighted association between them
[](/wiki/File:Simplified_neural_network_example.svg)

Subsequent run of the network on an input image (left):[\[136\]](#cite_note-136) The network correctly detects the starfishHowever, the weakly weighted association between ringed texture and sea urchin also confers a weak signal to the latter from one of two intermediate nodes

In addition, a shell that was not included in the training gives a weak signal for the oval shape, also resulting in a weak signal for the sea urchin outputThese weak signals may result in a [false positive](/wiki/False_positive "False positive") result for sea urchin 
In reality, textures and outlines would not be represented by single nodes, but rather by associated weight patterns of multiple nodes

**Artificial neural networks** (**ANNs**) or **[connectionist](/wiki/Connectionism "Connectionism") systems** are computing systems inspired by the [biological neural networks](/wiki/Biological_neural_network "Biological neural network") that constitute animal brainsSuch systems learn (progressively improve their ability) to do tasks by considering examples, generally without task-specific programmingFor example, in image recognition, they might learn to identify images that contain cats by analyzing example images that have been manually [labeled](/wiki/Labeled_data "Labeled data") as "cat" or "no cat" and using the analytic results to identify cats in other images

They have found most use in applications difficult to express with a traditional computer algorithm using [rule-based programming](/wiki/Rule-based_programming "Rule-based programming")
An ANN is based on a collection of connected units called [artificial neurons](/wiki/Artificial_neuron "Artificial neuron"), (analogous to biological neurons in a [biological brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain"))Each connection ([synapse](/wiki/Synapse "Synapse")) between neurons can transmit a signal to another neuronThe receiving (postsynaptic) neuron can process the signal(s) and then signal downstream neurons connected to it

Neurons may have state, generally represented by [real numbers](/wiki/Real_numbers "Real numbers"), typically between 0 and 1Neurons and synapses may also have a weight that varies as learning proceeds, which can increase or decrease the strength of the signal that it sends downstream
Typically, neurons are organized in layersDifferent layers may perform different kinds of transformations on their inputsSignals travel from the first (input), to the last (output) layer, possibly after traversing the layers multiple times

The original goal of the neural network approach was to solve problems in the same way that a human brain wouldOver time, attention focused on matching specific mental abilities, leading to deviations from biology such as [backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation "Backpropagation"), or passing information in the reverse direction and adjusting the network to reflect that information

Neural networks have been used on a variety of tasks, including computer vision, [speech recognition](/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition"), [machine translation](/wiki/Machine_translation "Machine translation"), [social network](/wiki/Social_network "Social network") filtering, [playing board and video games](/wiki/General_game_playing "General game playing") and medical diagnosis
As of 2017, neural networks typically have a few thousand to a few million units and millions of connections

Despite this number being several order of magnitude less than the number of neurons on a human brain, these networks can perform many tasks at a level beyond that of humans (e.g., recognizing faces, or playing "Go"[\[137\]](#cite_note-137))

###Deepneuralnetworks\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=7"Editsection:Deepneuralnetworks")\]

Adeepneuralnetwork(DNN)isan[artificialneuralnetwork](/wiki/Artificial_neural_network"Artificialneuralnetwork")(ANN)withmultiplelayersbetweentheinputandoutputlayers.[\[10\]](#cite_note-BENGIODEEP-10)[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13)Therearedifferenttypesofneuralnetworksbuttheyalwaysconsistofthesamecomponents:neurons,synapses,weights,biases,andfunctions.[\[138\]](#cite_note-Nokkada-138)Thesecomponentsasawholefunctionsimilarlytoahumanbrain,andcanbetrainedlikeanyotherMLalgorithm.\[_[citationneeded](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed"Wikipedia:Citationneeded")_\]

Forexample,aDNNthatistrainedtorecognizedogbreedswillgooverthegivenimageandcalculatetheprobabilitythatthedogintheimageisacertainbreedThe user can review the results and select which probabilities the network should display (above a certain threshold, etc.) and return the proposed labelEach mathematical manipulation as such is considered a layer,\[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] and complex DNN have many layers, hence the name "deep" networks
DNNs can model complex non-linear relationships

DNN architectures generate compositional models where the object is expressed as a layered composition of [primitives](/wiki/Primitive_data_type "Primitive data type").[\[139\]](#cite_note-139) The extra layers enable composition of features from lower layers, potentially modeling complex data with fewer units than a similarly performing shallow network.[\[10\]](#cite_note-BENGIODEEP-10) For instance, it was proved that sparse [multivariate polynomials](/wiki/Multivariate_polynomial "Multivariate polynomial") are exponentially easier to approximate with DNNs than with shallow networks.[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)

Deep architectures include many variants of a few basic approachesEach architecture has found success in specific domains

It is not always possible to compare the performance of multiple architectures, unless they have been evaluated on the same data sets
DNNs are typically feedforward networks in which data flows from the input layer to the output layer without looping backAt first, the DNN creates a map of virtual neurons and assigns random numerical values, or "weights", to connections between themThe weights and inputs are multiplied and return an output between 0 and 1

If the network did not accurately recognize a particular pattern, an algorithm would adjust the weights.[\[141\]](#cite_note-141) That way the algorithm can make certain parameters more influential, until it determines the correct mathematical manipulation to fully process the data

[Recurrent neural networks](/wiki/Recurrent_neural_networks "Recurrent neural networks") (RNNs), in which data can flow in any direction, are used for applications such as [language modeling](/wiki/Language_model "Language model").[\[142\]](#cite_note-gers2001-142)[\[143\]](#cite_note-NIPS2014-143)[\[144\]](#cite_note-vinyals2016-144)[\[145\]](#cite_note-gillick2015-145)[\[146\]](#cite_note-MIKO2010-146) Long short-term memory is particularly effective for this use.[\[75\]](#cite_note-:0-75)[\[147\]](#cite_note-:10-147)

[Convolutional deep neural networks (CNNs)](/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network "Convolutional neural network") are used in computer vision.[\[148\]](#cite_note-LECUN86-148) CNNs also have been applied to [acoustic modeling](/wiki/Acoustic_model "Acoustic model") for automatic speech recognition (ASR).[\[149\]](#cite_note-:2-149)

#### Challenges\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Challenges")\]

As with ANNs, many issues can arise with naively trained DNNsTwo common issues are [overfitting](/wiki/Overfitting "Overfitting") and computation time
DNNs are prone to overfitting because of the added layers of abstraction, which allow them to model rare dependencies in the training data

[Regularization](/wiki/Regularization_(mathematics) "Regularization (mathematics)") methods such as Ivakhnenko's unit pruning[\[34\]](#cite_note-ivak1971-34) or [weight decay](/wiki/Weight_decay "Weight decay") ( ℓ 2 {\\displaystyle \\ell \_{2}} \\ell \_{2}\-regularization) or [sparsity](/wiki/Sparse_matrix "Sparse matrix") ( ℓ 1 {\\displaystyle \\ell \_{1}} \\ell \_{1}\-regularization) can be applied during training to combat overfitting.[\[150\]](#cite_note-150) Alternatively [dropout](/wiki/Dropout_(neural_networks) "Dropout (neural networks)") regularization randomly omits units from the hidden layers during training

This helps to exclude rare dependencies.[\[151\]](#cite_note-DAHL2013-151) Finally, data can be augmented via methods such as cropping and rotating such that smaller training sets can be increased in size to reduce the chances of overfitting.[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)

DNNs must consider many training parameters, such as the size (number of layers and number of units per layer), the [learning rate](/wiki/Learning_rate "Learning rate"), and initial weights

[Sweeping through the parameter space](/wiki/Hyperparameter_optimization#Grid_search "Hyperparameter optimization") for optimal parameters may not be feasible due to the cost in time and computational resourcesVarious tricks, such as batching (computing the gradient on several training examples at once rather than individual examples)[\[153\]](#cite_note-RBMTRAIN-153) speed up computation

Large processing capabilities of many-core architectures (such as GPUs or the Intel Xeon Phi) have produced significant speedups in training, because of the suitability of such processing architectures for the matrix and vector computations.[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)

Alternatively, engineers may look for other types of neural networks with more straightforward and convergent training algorithmsCMAC ([cerebellar model articulation controller](/wiki/Cerebellar_model_articulation_controller "Cerebellar model articulation controller")) is one such kind of neural networkIt doesn't require learning rates or randomized initial weights

The training process can be guaranteed to converge in one step with a new batch of data, and the computational complexity of the training algorithm is linear with respect to the number of neurons involved.[\[156\]](#cite_note-Qin1-156)[\[157\]](#cite_note-Qin2-157)

### Automatic speech recognition\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Automatic speech recognition")\]

Main article: [Speech recognition](/wiki/Speech_recognition "Speech recognition")

Large-scale automatic speech recognition is the first and most convincing successful case of deep learningLSTM RNNs can learn "Very Deep Learning" tasks[\[13\]](#cite_note-SCHIDHUB-13) that involve multi-second intervals containing speech events separated by thousands of discrete time steps, where one time step corresponds to about 10 ms

LSTM with forget gates[\[147\]](#cite_note-:10-147) is competitive with traditional speech recognizers on certain tasks.[\[92\]](#cite_note-graves2003-92)

The initial success in speech recognition was based on small-scale recognition tasks based on TIMITThe data set contains 630 speakers from eight major [dialects](/wiki/Dialect "Dialect") of [American English](/wiki/American_English "American English"), where each speaker reads 10 sentences.[\[168\]](#cite_note-LDCTIMIT-168) Its small size lets many configurations be triedMore importantly, the TIMIT task concerns [phone](/wiki/Phone_(phonetics) "Phone (phonetics)")\-sequence recognition, which, unlike word-sequence recognition, allows weak phone [bigram](/wiki/Bigram "Bigram") language models

This lets the strength of the acoustic modeling aspects of speech recognition be more easily analyzedThe error rates listed below, including these early results and measured as percent phone error rates (PER), have been summarized since 1991

### Image recognition\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Image recognition")\]

Main article: [Computer vision](/wiki/Computer_vision "Computer vision")

A common evaluation set for image classification is the [MNIST database](/wiki/MNIST_database "MNIST database") data setMNIST is composed of handwritten digits and includes 60,000 training examples and 10,000 test examplesAs with TIMIT, its small size lets users test multiple configurationsA comprehensive list of results on this set is available.[\[175\]](#cite_note-YANNMNIST-175)

Deep learning-based image recognition has become "superhuman", producing more accurate results than human contestants

This first occurred in 2011 in recognition of traffic signs, and in 2014, with recognition of human faces.[\[176\]](#cite_note-:7-176)[\[177\]](#cite_note-surpass1-177)

Deep learning-trained vehicles now interpret 360° camera views.[\[178\]](#cite_note-178) Another example is Facial Dysmorphology Novel Analysis (FDNA) used to analyze cases of human malformation connected to a large database of genetic syndromes

### Visual art processing\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Visual art processing")\]

[](/wiki/File:Jimmy_Wales_in_France,_with_the_style_of_Munch%27s_%22The_Scream%22_applied_using_neural_style_transfer.jpg)

Visual art processing of Jimmy Wales in France, with the style of Munch's "[The Scream](/wiki/The_Scream "The Scream")" applied using neural style transfer

Closely related to the progress that has been made in image recognition is the increasing application of deep learning techniques to various visual art tasks

DNNs have proven themselves capable, for example, of

*   identifying the style period of a given painting[\[179\]](#cite_note-art1-179)[\[180\]](#cite_note-art2-180)
*   [Neural Style Transfer](/wiki/Neural_Style_Transfer "Neural Style Transfer") – capturing the style of a given artwork and applying it in a visually pleasing manner to an arbitrary photograph or video[\[179\]](#cite_note-art1-179)[\[180\]](#cite_note-art2-180)
*   generating striking imagery based on random visual input fields.[\[179\]](#cite_note-art1-179)[\[180\]](#cite_note-art2-180)

### Natural language processing\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Natural language processing")\]

Main article: [Natural language processing](/wiki/Natural_language_processing "Natural language processing")

Neural networks have been used for implementing language models since the early 2000s.[\[142\]](#cite_note-gers2001-142) LSTM helped to improve machine translation and language modeling.[\[143\]](#cite_note-NIPS2014-143)[\[144\]](#cite_note-vinyals2016-144)[\[145\]](#cite_note-gillick2015-145)

Other key techniques in this field are negative sampling[\[181\]](#cite_note-GoldbergLevy2014-181) and [word embedding](/wiki/Word_embedding "Word embedding")

Word embedding, such as _[word2vec](/wiki/Word2vec "Word2vec")_, can be thought of as a representational layer in a deep learning architecture that transforms an atomic word into a positional representation of the word relative to other words in the dataset; the position is represented as a point in a [vector space](/wiki/Vector_space "Vector space")Using word embedding as an RNN input layer allows the network to parse sentences and phrases using an effective compositional vector grammarAcompositionalvectorgrammarcanbethoughtofas[probabilisticcontextfreegrammar](/wiki/Probabilistic_context_free_grammar"Probabilisticcontextfreegrammar")(PCFG)implementedbyanRNN.[\[182\]](#cite_note-SocherManning2014-182)Recursiveauto-encodersbuiltatopwordembeddingscanassesssentencesimilarityanddetectparaphrasing.[\[182\]](#cite_note-SocherManning2014-182)Deepneuralarchitecturesprovidethebestresultsfor[constituencyparsing](/wiki/Statistical_parsing"Statisticalparsing"),[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)[sentimentanalysis](/wiki/Sentiment_analysis"Sentimentanalysis"),[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)informationretrieval,[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)[\[186\]](#cite_note-186)spokenlanguageunderstanding,[\[187\]](#cite_note-IEEE-TASL2015-187)machinetranslation,[\[143\]](#cite_note-NIPS2014-143)[\[188\]](#cite_note-auto-188)contextualentitylinking,[\[188\]](#cite_note-auto-188)writingstylerecognition,[\[189\]](#cite_note-BROC2017-189)[named-entity

recognition](/wiki/Named-entity_recognition"Named-entityrecognition")(tokenclassification),[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)textclassification,andothers.[\[191\]](#cite_note-191)

Recentdevelopmentsgeneralize[wordembedding](/wiki/Word_embedding"Wordembedding")to[sentenceembedding](/wiki/Sentence_embedding"Sentenceembedding")
[Google Translate](/wiki/Google_Translate "Google Translate") (GT) uses a large end-to-end [long short-term memory](/wiki/Long_short-term_memory "Long short-term memory") (LSTM) network.[\[192\]](#cite_note-GT_Turovsky_2016-192)[\[193\]](#cite_note-googleblog_GNMT_2016-193)[\[194\]](#cite_note-GoogleTranslate-194)[\[195\]](#cite_note-WiredGoogleTranslate-195) [Google Neural Machine Translation (GNMT)](/wiki/Google_Neural_Machine_Translation "Google Neural Machine Translation") uses an [example-based machine translation](/wiki/Example-based_machine_translation "Example-based machine translation") method in which the system "learns from millions of examples".[\[193\]](#cite_note-googleblog_GNMT_2016-193) It translates "whole sentences at a time, rather than pieces"

Google Translate supports over one hundred languages.[\[193\]](#cite_note-googleblog_GNMT_2016-193) The network encodes the "semantics of the sentence rather than simply memorizing phrase-to-phrase translations".[\[193\]](#cite_note-googleblog_GNMT_2016-193)[\[196\]](#cite_note-Biotet-196) GT uses English as an intermediate between most language pairs.[\[196\]](#cite_note-Biotet-196)

### Customer relationship management\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Customer relationship management")\]

Main article: [Customer relationship management](/wiki/Customer_relationship_management "Customer relationship management")

[Deep reinforcement learning](/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning "Deep reinforcement learning") has been used to approximate the value of possible [direct marketing](/wiki/Direct_marketing "Direct marketing") actions, defined in terms of [RFM](/wiki/RFM_(customer_value) "RFM (customer value)") variables. The estimated value function was shown to have a natural interpretation as [customer lifetime value](/wiki/Customer_lifetime_value "Customer lifetime value").[\[205\]](#cite_note-205)

### Recommendation systems\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Recommendation systems")\]

Main article: [Recommender system](/wiki/Recommender_system "Recommender system")

Recommendation systems have used deep learning to extract meaningful features for a latent factor model for content-based music and journal recommendations.[\[206\]](#cite_note-206)[\[207\]](#cite_note-207) Multi-view deep learning has been applied for learning user preferences from multiple domains.[\[208\]](#cite_note-208) The model uses a hybrid collaborative and content-based approach and enhances recommendations in multiple tasks.

### Bioinformatics\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Bioinformatics")\]

Main article: [Bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics")

An [autoencoder](/wiki/Autoencoder "Autoencoder") ANN was used in [bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics"), to predict [gene ontology](/wiki/Gene_Ontology "Gene Ontology") annotations and gene-function relationships.[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)

In medical informatics, deep learning was used to predict sleep quality based on data from wearables[\[210\]](#cite_note-210) and predictions of health complications from [electronic health record](/wiki/Electronic_health_record "Electronic health record") data.[\[211\]](#cite_note-211)

### Medical image analysis\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Medical image analysis")\]

Deep learning has been shown to produce competitive results in medical application such as cancer cell classification, lesion detection, organ segmentation and image enhancement.[\[212\]](#cite_note-212)[\[213\]](#cite_note-213) Modern deep learning tools demonstrate the high accuracy of detecting various diseases and the helpfulness of their use by specialists to improve the diagnosis efficiency.[\[214\]](#cite_note-214)[\[215\]](#cite_note-215)

### Mobile advertising\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Mobile advertising")\]

Finding the appropriate mobile audience for [mobile advertising](/wiki/Mobile_advertising "Mobile advertising") is always challenging, since many data points must be considered and analyzed before a target segment can be created and used in ad serving by any ad server.[\[216\]](#cite_note-216) Deep learning has been used to interpret large, many-dimensioned advertising datasets. Many data points are collected during the request/serve/click internet advertising cycle. This information can form the basis of machine learning to improve ad selection.

### Image restoration\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Image restoration")\]

Deep learning has been successfully applied to [inverse problems](/wiki/Inverse_problems "Inverse problems") such as [denoising](/wiki/Denoising "Denoising"), [super-resolution](/wiki/Super-resolution "Super-resolution"), [inpainting](/wiki/Inpainting "Inpainting"), and [film colorization](/wiki/Film_colorization "Film colorization").[\[217\]](#cite_note-217) These applications include learning methods such as "Shrinkage Fields for Effective Image Restoration"[\[218\]](#cite_note-218) which trains on an image dataset, and [Deep Image Prior](/wiki/Deep_Image_Prior "Deep Image Prior"), which trains on the image that needs restoration.

### Financial fraud detection\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Financial fraud detection")\]

Deep learning is being successfully applied to financial [fraud detection](/wiki/Fraud_detection "Fraud detection"), tax evasion detection,[\[219\]](#cite_note-219) and anti-money laundering.[\[220\]](#cite_note-220)

### Military\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Military")\]

The United States Department of Defense applied deep learning to train robots in new tasks through observation.[\[221\]](#cite_note-:12-221)

### Partial differential equations\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Partial differential equations")\]

Physics informed neural networks have been used to solve [partial differential equations](/wiki/Partial_differential_equation "Partial differential equation") in both forward and inverse problems in a data driven manner.[\[222\]](#cite_note-222) One example is the reconstructing fluid flow governed by the [Navier-Stokes equations](/wiki/Navier%E2%80%93Stokes_equations "Navier–Stokes equations"). Using physics informed neural networks does not require the often expensive mesh generation that conventional [CFD](/wiki/Computational_fluid_dynamics "Computational fluid dynamics") methods relies on.[\[223\]](#cite_note-223)[\[224\]](#cite_note-224)

### Image Reconstruction\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Image Reconstruction")\]

Image reconstruction is the reconstruction of the underlying images from the image-related measurements. Several works showed the better and superior performance of the deep learning methods compared to analytical methods for various applications, e.g., spectral imaging [\[225\]](#cite_note-225) and ultrasound imaging.[\[226\]](#cite_note-226)

### Epigenetic clock\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Epigenetic clock")\]

Main article: [Epigenetic clock](/wiki/Epigenetic_clock "Epigenetic clock")

An epigenetic clock is a [biochemical test](/wiki/Biomarkers_of_aging "Biomarkers of aging") that can be used to measure ageGalkin et alused deep neural networks to train an epigenetic aging clock of unprecedented accuracy using >6,000 blood samples.[\[227\]](#cite_note-227) The clock uses information from 1000 [CpG sites](/wiki/CpG_site "CpG site") and predicts people with certain conditions older than healthy controls: [IBD](/wiki/Inflammatory_bowel_disease "Inflammatory bowel disease"), [frontotemporal dementia](/wiki/Frontotemporal_dementia "Frontotemporal dementia"), [ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian cancer"), [obesity](/wiki/Obesity "Obesity")

The aging clock was planned to be released for public use in 2021 by an [Insilico Medicine](/wiki/Insilico_Medicine "Insilico Medicine") spinoff company Deep Longevity
Relation to human cognitive and brain development\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Relation to human cognitive and brain development")\]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Deep learning is closely related to a class of theories of [brain development](/wiki/Brain_development "Brain development") (specifically, neocortical development) proposed by [cognitive neuroscientists](/wiki/Cognitive_neuroscientist "Cognitive neuroscientist") in the early 1990s.[\[228\]](#cite_note-UTGOFF-228)[\[229\]](#cite_note-ELMAN-229)[\[230\]](#cite_note-SHRAGER-230)[\[231\]](#cite_note-QUARTZ-231) These developmental theories were instantiated in computational models, making them predecessors of deep learning systems

These developmental models share the property that various proposed learning dynamics in the brain (e.g., a wave of [nerve growth factor](/wiki/Nerve_growth_factor "Nerve growth factor")) support the [self-organization](/wiki/Self-organization "Self-organization") somewhat analogous to the neural networks utilized in deep learning modelsLike the [neocortex](/wiki/Neocortex "Neocortex"), neural networks employ a hierarchy of layered filters in which each layer considers information from a prior layer (or the operating environment), and then passes its output (and possibly the original input), to other layers

This process yields a self-organizing stack of [transducers](/wiki/Transducer "Transducer"), well-tuned to their operating environmentA 1995 description stated, "...the infant's brain seems to organize itself under the influence of waves of so-called trophic-factors ..different regions of the brain become connected sequentially, with one layer of tissue maturing before another and so on until the whole brain is mature".[\[232\]](#cite_note-BLAKESLEE-232)

A variety of approaches have been used to investigate the plausibility of deep learning models from a neurobiological perspectiveOntheonehand,severalvariantsofthe[backpropagation](/wiki/Backpropagation"Backpropagation")algorithmhavebeenproposedinordertoincreaseitsprocessingrealism.[\[233\]](#cite_note-233)[\[234\]](#cite_note-234)Otherresearchershavearguedthatunsupervisedformsofdeeplearning,suchasthosebasedonhierarchical[generativemodels](/wiki/Generative_model"Generativemodel")and[deepbeliefnetworks](/wiki/Deep_belief_network"Deepbeliefnetwork"),maybeclosertobiologicalreality.[\[235\]](#cite_note-235)[\[236\]](#cite_note-236)Inthisrespect,generativeneuralnetworkmodelshavebeenrelatedtoneurobiologicalevidenceaboutsampling-basedprocessinginthecerebralcortex.[\[237\]](#cite_note-237)

Althoughasystematiccomparisonbetweenthehumanbrainorganizationandtheneuronalencodingindeepnetworkshasnotyetbeenestablished,severalanalogieshavebeenreported

For example, the computations performed by deep learning units could be similar to those of actual neurons[\[238\]](#cite_note-238) and neural populations.[\[239\]](#cite_note-239) Similarly, the representations developed by deep learning models are similar to those measured in the primate visual system[\[240\]](#cite_note-240) both at the single-unit[\[241\]](#cite_note-241) and at the population[\[242\]](#cite_note-242) levels

Commercial activity\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Commercial activity")\]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook")'s AI lab performs tasks such as [automatically tagging uploaded pictures](/wiki/Automatic_image_annotation "Automatic image annotation") with the names of the people in them.[\[243\]](#cite_note-METZ2013-243)

Google's [DeepMind Technologies](/wiki/DeepMind_Technologies "DeepMind Technologies") developed a system capable of learning how to play [Atari](/wiki/Atari "Atari") video games using only pixels as data input

In 2015 they demonstrated their [AlphaGo](/wiki/AlphaGo "AlphaGo") system, which learned the game of [Go](/wiki/Go_(game) "Go (game)") well enough to beat a professional Go player.[\[244\]](#cite_note-244)[\[245\]](#cite_note-245)[\[246\]](#cite_note-246) [Google Translate](/wiki/Google_Translate "Google Translate") uses a neural network to translate between more than 100 languages
In2017,Covariant.aiwaslaunched,whichfocusesonintegratingdeeplearningintofactories.[\[247\]](#cite_note-247)

Asof2008,[\[248\]](#cite_note-248)researchersat[TheUniversityofTexasatAustin](/wiki/University_of_Texas_at_Austin"UniversityofTexasatAustin")(UT)developedamachinelearningframeworkcalledTraininganAgentManuallyviaEvaluativeReinforcement,orTAMER,whichproposednewmethodsforrobotsorcomputerprogramstolearnhowtoperformtasksbyinteractingwithahumaninstructor.[\[221\]](#cite_note-:12-221)FirstdevelopedasTAMER,anewalgorithmcalledDeepTAMERwaslaterintroducedin2018duringacollaborationbetween[U.SArmy Research Laboratory](/wiki/U.S._Army_Research_Laboratory "U.SArmy Research Laboratory") (ARL) and UT researchers

Deep TAMER used deep learning to provide a robot the ability to learn new tasks through observation.[\[221\]](#cite_note-:12-221) Using Deep TAMER, a robot learned a task with a human trainer, watching video streams or observing a human perform a task in-personThe robot later practiced the task with the help of some coaching from the trainer, who provided feedback such as "good job" and "bad job".[\[249\]](#cite_note-249)

Criticism and comment\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Criticism and comment")\]
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Deep learning has attracted both criticism and comment, in some cases from outside the field of computer science.

### Theory\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Theory")\]

See also: [Explainable artificial intelligence](/wiki/Explainable_artificial_intelligence "Explainable artificial intelligence")

A main criticism concerns the lack of theory surrounding some methods.[\[250\]](#cite_note-250) Learning in the most common deep architectures is implemented using well-understood gradient descentHowever, the theory surrounding other algorithms, such as contrastive divergence is less clear.\[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] (e.g., Does it convergeIf so, how fast

What is it approximating?) Deep learning methods are often looked at as a [black box](/wiki/Black_box "Black box"), with most confirmations done empirically, rather than theoretically.[\[251\]](#cite_note-Knight_2017-251)

Others point out that deep learning should be looked at as a step towards realizing [strong AI](/wiki/Strong_artificial_intelligence "Strong artificial intelligence"), not as an all-encompassing solutionDespite the power of deep learning methods, they still lack much of the functionality needed for realizing this goal entirely

Research psychologist [Gary Marcus](/wiki/Gary_Marcus "Gary Marcus") noted:

> Realistically, deep learning is only part of the larger challenge of building intelligent machinesSuch techniques lack ways of representing [causal relationships](/wiki/Causality "Causality") (...) have no obvious ways of performing [logical inferences](/wiki/Inference "Inference"), and they are also still a long way from integrating abstract knowledge, such as information about what objects are, what they are for, and how they are typically usedThe most powerful A.Isystems,like[Watson](/wiki/Watson_(computer)"Watson(computer)")(...)usetechniqueslikedeeplearningasjustoneelementinaverycomplicatedensembleoftechniques,rangingfromthestatisticaltechniqueof[Bayesianinference](/wiki/Bayesian_inference"Bayesianinference")to[deductivereasoning](/wiki/Deductive_reasoning"Deductivereasoning").[\[252\]](#cite_note-252)

Infurtherreferencetotheideathatartisticsensitivitymightbeinherentinrelativelylowlevelsofthecognitivehierarchy,apublishedseriesofgraphicrepresentationsoftheinternalstatesofdeep(20-30layers)neuralnetworksattemptingtodiscernwithinessentiallyrandomdatatheimagesonwhichtheyweretrained[\[253\]](#cite_note-253)demonstrateavisualappeal:theoriginalresearchnoticereceivedwellover1,000comments,andwasthesubjectofwhatwasforatimethemostfrequentlyaccessedarticleon_[TheGuardian](/wiki/The_Guardian"TheGuardian")'s_[\[254\]](#cite_note-254)website

While deep learning consists of dozens and even hundreds of layers, that architecture doesn't seem to resemble the structure of the brainSimulations on shallow networks, which are closer to the brain dynamics, indicate a similar performance as deep learning with a lower complexity.[\[255\]](#cite_note-255)[\[256\]](#cite_note-256)

### Cyber threat\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Cyber threat")\]

As deep learning moves from the lab into the world, research and experience show that [artificial neural networks](/wiki/Artificial_neural_networks "Artificial neural networks") are vulnerable to hacks and deception.[\[263\]](#cite_note-263) By identifying patterns that these systems use to function, attackers can modify inputs to ANNs in such a way that the ANN finds a match that human observers would not recognize

For example, an attacker can make subtle changes to an image such that the ANN finds a match even though the image looks to a human nothing like the search targetSuch manipulation is termed an "adversarial attack".[\[264\]](#cite_note-264)

In 2016 researchers used one ANN to doctor images in trial and error fashion, identify another's focal points and thereby generate images that deceived itThe modified images looked no different to human eyes

Another group showed that printouts of doctored images then photographed successfully tricked an image classification system.[\[265\]](#cite_note-:4-265) One defense is reverse image search, in which a possible fake image is submitted to a site such as [TinEye](/wiki/TinEye "TinEye") that can then find other instances of it

A refinement is to search using only parts of the image, to identify images from which that piece may have been taken**.**[\[266\]](#cite_note-266)

Another group showed that certain [psychedelic](/wiki/Psychedelic_art "Psychedelic art") spectacles could fool a [facial recognition system](/wiki/Facial_recognition_system "Facial recognition system") into thinking ordinary people were celebrities, potentially allowing one person to impersonate another

In 2017 researchers added stickers to [stop signs](/wiki/Stop_sign "Stop sign") and caused an ANN to misclassify them.[\[265\]](#cite_note-:4-265)

ANNs can however be further trained to detect attempts at [deception](/wiki/Deception "Deception"), potentially leading attackers and defenders into an arms race similar to the kind that already defines the [malware](/wiki/Malware "Malware") defense industryANNshavebeentrainedtodefeatANN-basedanti-[malware](/wiki/Malware"Malware")softwarebyrepeatedlyattackingadefensewithmalwarethatwascontinuallyalteredbya[geneticalgorithm](/wiki/Genetic_algorithm"Geneticalgorithm")untilittrickedtheanti-malwarewhileretainingitsabilitytodamagethetarget.[\[265\]](#cite_note-:4-265)

In2016,anothergroupdemonstratedthatcertainsoundscouldmakethe[GoogleNow](/wiki/Google_Now"GoogleNow")voicecommandsystemopenaparticularwebaddress,andhypothesizedthatthiscould"serveasasteppingstoneforfurtherattacks(e.g.,openingawebpagehostingdrive-bymalware)".[\[265\]](#cite_note-:4-265)

In"[datapoisoning](/wiki/Adversarial_machine_learning#Data_poisoning"Adversarialmachinelearning")",falsedataiscontinuallysmuggledintoamachinelearningsystem'strainingsettopreventitfromachievingmastery.[\[265\]](#cite_note-:4-265)

### Data collection ethics\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Deep_learning&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Data collection ethics")\]

[](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)

This section **needs additional citations for [verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**Please help [improve this article](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Deep_learning "Special:EditPage/Deep learning") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this sectionUnsourced material may be challenged and removed

_Find sources:_ ["Deep learning"](https://www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&q=%22Deep+learning%22) – [news](https://www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&q=%22Deep+learning%22+-wikipedia&tbs=ar:1) **·** [newspapers](https://www.google.com/search?&q=%22Deep+learning%22&tbs=bkt:s&tbm=bks) **·** [books](https://www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&q=%22Deep+learning%22+-wikipedia) **·** [scholar](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Deep+learning%22) **·** [JSTOR](https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Deep+learning%22&acc=on&wc=on) _(April 2021)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_

Most Deep Learning systems rely on training and verification data that is generated and/or annotated by humans.[\[267\]](#cite_note-267) It has been argued in [media philosophy](/wiki/Media_studies "Media studies") that not only low-paid [clickwork](/wiki/Clickworkers "Clickworkers") (e.g

on [Amazon Mechanical Turk](/wiki/Amazon_Mechanical_Turk "Amazon Mechanical Turk")) is regularly deployed for this purpose, but also implicit forms of human [microwork](/wiki/Microwork "Microwork") that are often not recognized as such.[\[268\]](#cite_note-:13-268) The philosopher Rainer Mühlhoff distinguishes five types of "machinic capture" of human microwork to generate training data: (1) [gamification](/wiki/Gamification "Gamification") (the embedding of annotation or computation tasks in the flow of a game), (2) "trapping and tracking" (e.g

[CAPTCHAs](/wiki/CAPTCHA "CAPTCHA") for image recognition or click-tracking on Google [search results pages](/wiki/Search_engine_results_page "Search engine results page")), (3) exploitation of social motivations (e.g[tagging faces](/wiki/Tag_(Facebook) "Tag (Facebook)") on [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook") to obtain labeled facial images), (4) [information mining](/wiki/Information_mining "Information mining") (e.g

by leveraging [quantified-self](/wiki/Quantified_self "Quantified self") devices such as [activity trackers](/wiki/Activity_tracker "Activity tracker")) and (5) [clickwork](/wiki/Clickworkers "Clickworkers").[\[268\]](#cite_note-:13-268)

Mühlhoff argues that in most commercial end-user applications of Deep Learning such as [Facebook's face recognition system](/wiki/DeepFace "DeepFace"), the need for training data does not stop once an ANN is trainedRather, there is a continued demand for human-generated verification data to constantly calibrate and update the ANN

For this purpose Facebook introduced the feature that once a user is automatically recognized in an image, they receive a notificationThey can choose whether of not they like to be publicly labeled on the image, or tell Facebook that it is not them in the picture.[\[269\]](#cite_note-269) This user interface is a mechanism to generate "a constant stream of verification data"[\[268\]](#cite_note-:13-268) to further train the network in real-time

As Mühlhoff argues, involvement of human users to generate training and verification data is so typical for most commercial end-user applications of Deep Learning that such systems may be referred to as "human-aided artificial intelligence".[\[268\]](#cite_note-:13-268)
